Madam Speaker, I stand before this august House to open the discussion on the Motion of Thanks on the President’s Address on behalf of my colleagues. आदरणीय अध्यक्ष जी, सर्वप्रथम तो मैं माननीय महामहिम राष्ट्रपति जी को धन्यवाद देना चाहती हूं कि उन्होंने अपने अभिभाषण में देश हित को लेकर अनेक महत्वपूर्ण मुद्दे उठाए एवम् मुख्य बिंदुओं पर चर्चा की। हम सबको उन्हें सुनने का मौका मिला। To begin with, from the beginning, Madam, India for long, was at the cusp of reaching the pinnacle of global leadership as a major epicenter of economic, military and soft power. Yet years became decades and that did not happen. In spite of all advantages in the form of democracy, demography and demand, somewhere India remained mired in its own problems. The world kept waiting for us, but we were too reluctant to board the bus. It was not pacifism but also some sort fascination for some illusionary socialistic model that brought India down in the early Nineties. The beginning of the new millennium did offer many opportunities and major opportunities for India to take the whole position. Global politics was changing; Asia was becoming the hub of manufacturing; and China was racing past the west, and once again, India was poised. The Telecom Revolution, the Golden Quadrilateral were some projects, which did shape up India to an extent, yet for decades, since then, India did not board the bus once again. Policy paralysis, rampant corruption, appeasement politics, nepotism, red-tapism and giving priority to populist measures rather than the real welfare issues, became the policy of this country, which put India in a very poor light and the future looked really bleak. When Shri Narendra Modi’s Government took over the mantle, India was known more for corruption than anything else. The 2G scam, CWG scam, coal scam, and the list of scams just goes on, became the talking point for the world. Investors were shying away from investing in India. Modernization of Armed Forces was pending for a decade. There was lack of optimism both within the country, inside the country and outside the country. It was then the Narendra Modi Government emerged. Hon. Speaker Madam, I take this opportunity to put forward some of the initiatives of this Government to fulfil the aspirations of 126 crore Indians. India became the fastest growing economy. Our governance paradigm seeks to undertake development and development for each and every section of this country and of this society. Our goal is to reach out to the poorest of the poor, every section of society and to the remotest corner of the county and ensure delivery of services and effective policy making in this regard. Economic development alongside social justice in a time bound manner needs coordination and efficient implementation through all stakeholders – be it States, local Governments, businesses, NGOs and most importantly, people of this nation. The process has been slow because of the enormity of the situation and the task ahead. Reforms are relatively slow but effective methodology for achieving the goals requires constructive blending of skills, capital and reform mechanism. In this regard, whether it is in the area of skilling, it is in the area of getting investments or having reformist attitude towards various reform mechanisms or regulatory mechanism, the Government has actually been very serious and is working towards that. The Government of India’s centre piece programme for changing or transforming the country is actually ‘Make in India’. ‘Make in India’ has three major parts –construction of infrastructure, Railways and defence, and these three along with Telecom sector are going to transform the way our country progressed till now and is likely to progress in future. The paradigm shift to transform India is definitely that we are inching towards our goals and India is likely to become the global manufacturing powerhouse. Since its launch, the Prime Minister, Mr. Modi has pulled all steps, all full stops for the global participation is India’s story. In the recently concluded ‘Make in India Week’ in Maharashtra, projects worth eight lakh crore rupees have been inked. More than two lakh jobs, thus, shall be created. Our manufacturing landscape is in the process of rapid reforms whereas ‘Ease of Doing Business’ is facilitated by the Government and many State Governments have their own transformatory objective to achieve and participate in nation building. 12.28 hours (Shri Anandrao Adsulin the Chair) The related business with respect to ‘Make in India’ is integration of various opportunities which are available to business houses, respective States, national and international stakeholders to provide win-win situation and economic climate for all. The programme is designed to facilitate investment, foster innovation, enhance skill development, protect intellectual property and build best in class manufacturing infrastructure. The ‘Make in India’ initiative has created fans and admirers both domestically and internationally and global leaders are also admiring this process. Steps are being undertaken to delicense and deregulate the industry during the entire life cycle of the business. High value industrial sectors are sought to be created and FDI liberalisation has actually brought in FDI in this country. To specify a few statistics, the FDI cap has been raised from 26 per cent to 49 per cent, portfolio investment in defence sector permitted up to 24 per cent under the automatic route and 100 FDI allowed in defence sector for modern and state-of-art technology on case to case basis.
